title.en: Biographies of Bai Qi and Wang Jian
title.raw: 《白起王翦列傳》 Biographies of Bai Qi and Wang Jian

meta.citation: Translation: Partial translation by Garrett M. Petersen; remaining portions by Garrett M. Petersen (2025)

sentences.zh: 白起者，郿人也。

translations.text: Bai Qi was a native of Mei.

sentences.zh: 善用兵，事秦昭王。

translations.text: He was skilled in warfare and served King Zhao of Qin.

sentences.zh: 昭王十三年，而白起為左庶長，將而擊韓之新城。

translations.text: In the thirteenth year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi became left senior minister and led troops to attack Han's Xincheng.

sentences.zh: 是歲，穰侯相秦，舉任鄙以為漢中守。

translations.text: That year, the Marquis of Rang served as prime minister of Qin and appointed Ren Bi as governor of Hanzhong.

sentences.zh: 其明年，白起為左更，攻韓、魏於伊闕，斬首二十四萬，又虜其將公孫喜，拔五城。

translations.text: The next year, Bai Qi became left minister of the interior and attacked Han and Wei at Yique. He beheaded 240,000 men, captured their general Gongsun Xi, and took five cities.

sentences.zh: 起遷為國尉。

translations.text: Qi was promoted to state defender.

sentences.zh: 涉河取韓安邑以東，到乾河。

translations.text: He crossed the Yellow River and took Han's Anyi and eastward to Ganhe.

sentences.zh: 明年，白起為大良造。

translations.text: The next year, Bai Qi became grand master craftsman.

sentences.zh: 攻魏，拔之，取城小大六十一。

translations.text: He attacked Wei, conquered it, and took sixty-one cities of varying sizes.

sentences.zh: 明年，起與客卿錯攻垣城，拔之。

translations.text: The next year, Qi and guest minister Cuo attacked Yuan City and conquered it.

sentences.zh: 後五年，白起攻趙，拔光狼城。

translations.text: Five years later, Bai Qi attacked Zhao and conquered Guanglang City.

sentences.zh: 後七年，白起攻楚，拔鄢、鄧五城。

translations.text: Seven years later, Bai Qi attacked Chu and conquered Yan and Deng—five cities in total.

sentences.zh: 其明年，攻楚，拔郢，燒夷陵，遂東至竟陵。

translations.text: The next year, he attacked Chu again, conquered Ying, burned Yiling, and advanced east to Jingling.

sentences.zh: 楚王亡去郢，東走徙陳。

translations.text: The King of Chu fled Ying and moved east to Chen.

sentences.zh: 秦以郢為南郡。

translations.text: Qin made Ying into Nanhun Commandery.

sentences.zh: 白起遷為武安君。

translations.text: Bai Qi was promoted to Lord Wu'an.

sentences.zh: 武安君因取楚，定巫、黔中郡。

translations.text: Lord Wu'an then conquered Chu and established the commanderies of Wu and Qianzhong.

sentences.zh: 昭王三十四年，白起攻魏，拔華陽，走芒卯，而虜三晉將，斬首十三萬。

translations.text: In the thirty-fourth year of King Zhao, Bai Qi attacked Wei, conquered Huayang, routed Mang Mao, captured three Jin generals, and beheaded 130,000 men.

sentences.zh: 與趙將賈偃戰，沈其卒二萬人於河中。

translations.text: He fought with Zhao general Jia Yan and drowned 20,000 of his troops in the river.

sentences.zh: 昭王四十三年，白起攻韓陘城，拔五城，斬首五萬。

translations.text: In the forty-third year of King Zhao, Bai Qi attacked Han's Xingcheng, conquered five cities, and beheaded 50,000 men.

sentences.zh: 四十四年，白起攻南陽太行道，絕之。

translations.text: In the forty-fourth year, Bai Qi attacked the Nanyang-Taihang road and cut it off.

Bai Qi was a native of Mei. He was skilled in warfare and served King Zhao of Qin. In the thirteenth year of King Zhao's reign, Bai Qi became left senior minister and led troops to attack Han's Xincheng. That year, the Marquis of Rang served as prime minister of Qin and appointed Ren Bi as governor of Hanzhong. The next year, Bai Qi became left minister of the interior and attacked Han and Wei at Yique. He beheaded 240,000 men, captured their general Gongsun Xi, and took five cities. Qi was promoted to state defender. He crossed the Yellow River and took Han's Anyi and eastward to Ganhe. The next year, Bai Qi became grand master craftsman. He attacked Wei, conquered it, and took sixty-one cities of varying sizes. The next year, Qi and guest minister Cuo attacked Yuan City and conquered it. Five years later, Bai Qi attacked Zhao and conquered Guanglang City. Seven years later, Bai Qi attacked Chu and conquered Yan and Deng—five cities in total. The next year, he attacked Chu again, conquered Ying, burned Yiling, and advanced east to Jingling. The King of Chu fled Ying and moved east to Chen. Qin made Ying into Nanhun Commandery. Bai Qi was promoted to Lord Wu'an. Lord Wu'an then conquered Chu and established the commanderies of Wu and Qianzhong. In the thirty-fourth year of King Zhao, Bai Qi attacked Wei, conquered Huayang, routed Mang Mao, captured three Jin generals, and beheaded 130,000 men. He fought with Zhao general Jia Yan and drowned 20,000 of his troops in the river. In the forty-third year of King Zhao, Bai Qi attacked Han's Xingcheng, conquered five cities, and beheaded 50,000 men. In the forty-fourth year, Bai Qi attacked the Nanyang-Taihang road and cut it off.

sentences.zh: 四十五年，伐韓之野王。

translations.text: In the forty-fifth year, he attacked Han's Yewang.

sentences.zh: 野王降秦，上黨道絕。

translations.text: Yewang surrendered to Qin, cutting off the Shangdang road.

sentences.zh: 其守馮亭與民謀曰：「鄭道已絕，韓必不可得為民。

translations.text: Its defender Feng Ting consulted with the people, saying: 'The Zheng road is already cut. Han can no longer protect us as subjects.

sentences.zh: 秦兵日進，韓不能應，不如以上黨歸趙。

translations.text: Qin troops advance daily. Han cannot respond. Better to give Shangdang to Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙若受我，秦怒，必攻趙。

translations.text: If Zhao accepts us, Qin will be angry and must attack Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙被兵，必親韓。

translations.text: If Zhao suffers attack, it will certainly draw close to Han.

sentences.zh: 韓趙為一，則可以當秦。」

translations.text: If Han and Zhao unite, they can withstand Qin.'

sentences.zh: 因使人報趙。

translations.text: So they sent messengers to report to Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙孝成王與平陽君、平原君計之。

translations.text: King Xiaocheng of Zhao consulted with Lord Pingyang and Lord Pingyuan.

sentences.zh: 平陽君曰：「不如勿受。

translations.text: Lord Pingyang said: 'Better not to accept it.

sentences.zh: 受之，禍大於所得。」

translations.text: Accepting it brings disaster greater than the benefit gained.'

sentences.zh: 平原君曰：「無故得一郡，受之便。」

translations.text: Lord Pingyuan said: 'To gain a commandery for no reason—accepting it is advantageous.'

sentences.zh: 趙受之，因封馮亭為華陽君。

translations.text: Zhao accepted it and enfeoffed Feng Ting as Lord Huayang.

In the forty-fifth year, he attacked Han's Yewang. Yewang surrendered to Qin, cutting off the Shangdang road. Its defender Feng Ting consulted with the people, saying: 'The Zheng road is already cut. Han can no longer protect us as subjects. Qin troops advance daily. Han cannot respond. Better to give Shangdang to Zhao. If Zhao accepts us, Qin will be angry and must attack Zhao. If Zhao suffers attack, it will certainly draw close to Han. If Han and Zhao unite, they can withstand Qin.' So they sent messengers to report to Zhao. King Xiaocheng of Zhao consulted with Lord Pingyang and Lord Pingyuan. Lord Pingyang said: 'Better not to accept it. Accepting it brings disaster greater than the benefit gained.' Lord Pingyuan said: 'To gain a commandery for no reason—accepting it is advantageous.' Zhao accepted it and enfeoffed Feng Ting as Lord Huayang.

sentences.zh: 四十六年，秦攻韓緱氏、藺，拔之。

translations.text: In the forty-sixth year, Qin attacked Han's Gouzhi and Lin and conquered them.
In the forty-sixth year, Qin attacked Han's Gouzhi and Lin and conquered them.

sentences.zh: 四十七年，秦使左庶長王龁攻韓，取上黨。

translations.text: In the forty-seventh year, Qin sent left senior minister Wang He to attack Han and take Shangdang.

sentences.zh: 上黨民走趙。

translations.text: The people of Shangdang fled to Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙軍長平，以按據上黨民。

translations.text: Zhao stationed troops at Changping to control the Shangdang people.

sentences.zh: 四月，龁因攻趙。

translations.text: In the fourth month, He attacked Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙使廉頗將。

translations.text: Zhao sent Lian Po to command the army.

sentences.zh: 趙軍士卒犯秦斥兵，秦斥兵斬趙裨將茄。

translations.text: Zhao troops violated Qin's outposts. Qin outposts beheaded Zhao assistant general Jia.

sentences.zh: 六月，陷趙軍，取二鄣四尉。

translations.text: In the sixth month, they trapped Zhao troops and took two fortifications and four commandants.

sentences.zh: 七月，趙軍筑壘壁而守之。

translations.text: In the seventh month, Zhao troops built ramparts and defended them.

sentences.zh: 秦又攻其壘，取二尉，敗其陣，奪西壘壁。

translations.text: Qin attacked their ramparts again, took two commandants, defeated their battle formation, and seized the west ramparts and walls.

sentences.zh: 廉頗堅壁以待秦，秦數挑戰，趙兵不出。

translations.text: Lian Po held firm to his defenses awaiting Qin. Qin challenged them many times, but Zhao troops did not come out.

sentences.zh: 趙王數以為讓。

translations.text: The King of Zhao repeatedly rebuked him for it.

sentences.zh: 而秦相應侯又使人行千金於趙為反閒，曰：「秦之所惡，獨畏馬服子趙括將耳，廉頗易與，且降矣。」

translations.text: Meanwhile, Qin's prime minister Lord Ying sent agents with a thousand jin to Zhao to sow dissension, saying: 'What Qin fears most is only that Ma Fuzi Zhao Kuo will command the army. Lian Po is easy to deal with—he will soon surrender.'

sentences.zh: 趙王既怒廉頗軍多失亡，軍數敗，又反堅壁不敢戰，而又聞秦反閒之言，因使趙括代廉頗將以擊秦。

translations.text: The King of Zhao was already angry that Lian Po's army had suffered many losses and been defeated several times. Moreover, he heard the rumors of Qin's dissension. So he sent Zhao Kuo to replace Lian Po and attack Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦聞馬服子將，乃陰使武安君白起為上將軍。

translations.text: When Qin heard that Ma Fuzi was commanding, they secretly sent Lord Wu'an Bai Qi to be supreme general.

sentences.zh: 而王龁為尉裨將，令軍中有敢泄武安君將者斬。

translations.text: Wang He became assistant general, and they ordered that anyone in the army who dared leak that Lord Wu'an was commanding would be executed.

sentences.zh: 趙括至，則出兵擊秦軍。

translations.text: When Zhao Kuo arrived, he led troops out to attack the Qin army.

sentences.zh: 秦軍詳敗而走，張二奇兵以劫之。

translations.text: The Qin army feigned defeat and retreated, deploying two surprise forces to ambush them.

sentences.zh: 趙軍逐勝，追造秦壁。

translations.text: Zhao troops pursued their victory, chasing right up to Qin's walls.

sentences.zh: 壁堅拒不得入，而秦奇兵二萬五千人絕趙軍後，又一軍五千騎絕趙壁閒，趙軍分而為二，糧道絕。

translations.text: The walls held firm and could not be entered. Meanwhile, Qin's 25,000 surprise troops cut off Zhao's rear, and another force of 5,000 cavalry cut across Zhao's walls. Zhao's army was divided in two, and their grain route was cut.

sentences.zh: 而秦出輕兵擊之。

translations.text: Qin then sent light troops to attack them.

sentences.zh: 趙戰不利，因筑壁堅守，以待救至。

translations.text: Zhao fought unsuccessfully and built fortifications to defend firmly, awaiting rescue.

sentences.zh: 秦王聞趙食道絕，王自之河內，賜民爵各一級，發年十五以上悉詣長平，遮絕趙救及糧食。

translations.text: When the King of Qin heard that Zhao's food routes were cut, he went personally to Henei, granted each commoner one rank in nobility, and mobilized all men fifteen and older to go to Changping to block Zhao's rescue forces and supplies.

In the forty-seventh year, Qin sent left senior minister Wang He to attack Han and take Shangdang. The people of Shangdang fled to Zhao. Zhao stationed troops at Changping to control the Shangdang people. In the fourth month, He attacked Zhao. Zhao sent Lian Po to command the army. Zhao troops violated Qin's outposts. Qin outposts beheaded Zhao assistant general Jia. In the sixth month, they trapped Zhao troops and took two fortifications and four commandants. In the seventh month, Zhao troops built ramparts and defended them. Qin attacked their ramparts again, took two commandants, defeated their battle formation, and seized the west ramparts and walls. Lian Po held firm to his defenses awaiting Qin. Qin challenged them many times, but Zhao troops did not come out. The King of Zhao repeatedly rebuked him for it. Meanwhile, Qin's prime minister Lord Ying sent agents with a thousand jin to Zhao to sow dissension, saying: 'What Qin fears most is only that Ma Fuzi Zhao Kuo will command the army. Lian Po is easy to deal with—he will soon surrender.' The King of Zhao was already angry that Lian Po's army had suffered many losses and been defeated several times. Moreover, he heard the rumors of Qin's dissension. So he sent Zhao Kuo to replace Lian Po and attack Qin. When Qin heard that Ma Fuzi was commanding, they secretly sent Lord Wu'an Bai Qi to be supreme general. Wang He became assistant general, and they ordered that anyone in the army who dared leak that Lord Wu'an was commanding would be executed. When Zhao Kuo arrived, he led troops out to attack the Qin army. The Qin army feigned defeat and retreated, deploying two surprise forces to ambush them. Zhao troops pursued their victory, chasing right up to Qin's walls. The walls held firm and could not be entered. Meanwhile, Qin's 25,000 surprise troops cut off Zhao's rear, and another force of 5,000 cavalry cut across Zhao's walls. Zhao's army was divided in two, and their grain route was cut. Qin then sent light troops to attack them. Zhao fought unsuccessfully and built fortifications to defend firmly, awaiting rescue. When the King of Qin heard that Zhao's food routes were cut, he went personally to Henei, granted each commoner one rank in nobility, and mobilized all men fifteen and older to go to Changping to block Zhao's rescue forces and supplies.

sentences.zh: 至九月，趙卒不得食四十六日，皆內陰相殺食。

translations.text: By the ninth month, Zhao troops had gone forty-six days without food. They all secretly killed and ate each other.

sentences.zh: 來攻秦壘，欲出。

translations.text: They came to attack Qin's fortifications, wishing to break out.

sentences.zh: 為四隊，四五復之，不能出。

translations.text: They formed four teams and repeatedly tried four or five times, but could not break out.

sentences.zh: 其將軍趙括出銳卒自搏戰，秦軍射殺趙括。

translations.text: Their general Zhao Kuo led elite troops out to fight personally. Qin troops shot and killed Zhao Kuo.

sentences.zh: 括軍敗，卒四十萬人降武安君。

translations.text: Kuo's army was defeated. 400,000 troops surrendered to Lord Wu'an.

sentences.zh: 武安君計曰：「前秦已拔上黨，上黨民不樂為秦而歸趙。

translations.text: Lord Wu'an calculated: 'Previously Qin had conquered Shangdang, but the Shangdang people were unhappy serving Qin and went to Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙卒反覆。

translations.text: Zhao troops are fickle.

sentences.zh: 非盡殺之，恐為亂。」

translations.text: If we don't kill them all, they may cause rebellion.'

sentences.zh: 乃挾詐而盡阬殺之，遺其小者二百四十人歸趙。

translations.text: So he used deception to bury and kill them all alive, sending only the young ones—240 people—back to Zhao.

sentences.zh: 前後斬首虜四十五萬人。

translations.text: In total, they beheaded and captured 450,000 men before and after.

sentences.zh: 趙人大震。

translations.text: Zhao was greatly shaken.

By the ninth month, Zhao troops had gone forty-six days without food. They all secretly killed and ate each other. They came to attack Qin's fortifications, wishing to break out. They formed four teams and repeatedly tried four or five times, but could not break out. Their general Zhao Kuo led elite troops out to fight personally. Qin troops shot and killed Zhao Kuo. Kuo's army was defeated. 400,000 troops surrendered to Lord Wu'an. Lord Wu'an calculated: 'Previously Qin had conquered Shangdang, but the Shangdang people were unhappy serving Qin and went to Zhao. Zhao troops are fickle. If we don't kill them all, they may cause rebellion.' So he used deception to bury and kill them all alive, sending only the young ones—240 people—back to Zhao. In total, they beheaded and captured 450,000 men before and after. Zhao was greatly shaken.

sentences.zh: 四十八年十月，秦復定上黨郡。

translations.text: In the tenth month of the forty-eighth year, Qin reestablished Shangdang Commandery.

sentences.zh: 秦分軍為二：王龁攻皮牢，拔之；

translations.text: Qin divided their army into two: Wang He attacked Pi Lao and conquered it;

sentences.zh: 司馬梗定太原。

translations.text: Sima Geng pacified Taiyuan.

sentences.zh: 韓、趙恐，使蘇代厚幣說秦相應侯曰：「武安君禽馬服子乎？」

translations.text: Han and Zhao were afraid and sent Su Dai with rich bribes to persuade Qin's prime minister Lord Ying, saying: 'Has Lord Wu'an captured Ma Fuzi?'
'Yes.'

sentences.zh: 又曰：「即圍邯鄲乎？」

translations.text: 'Will he now besiege Handan?'
'Yes.'

sentences.zh: 「趙亡則秦王王矣，武安君為三公。

translations.text: 'If Zhao perishes, the King of Qin will become hegemon. Lord Wu'an will become one of the Three Dukes.

sentences.zh: 武安君所為秦戰勝攻取者七十餘城，南定鄢、郢、漢中，北禽趙括之軍，雖周、召、呂望之功不益於此矣。

translations.text: Lord Wu'an's victories for Qin—conquering over seventy cities, pacifying Yan and Ying in the south, taking Hanzhong, capturing Zhao Kuo's army in the north—even the achievements of Zhou Gong, Shao Gong, and Lu Wang would not surpass this.

sentences.zh: 今趙亡，秦王王，則武安君必為三公，君能為之下乎？

translations.text: Now if Zhao perishes and the King of Qin becomes hegemon, Lord Wu'an will certainly become one of the Three Dukes. Can you serve beneath him?

sentences.zh: 雖無欲為之下，固不得已矣。

translations.text: Even if you don't want to serve beneath him, you will have no choice.'

sentences.zh: 秦嘗攻韓，圍邢丘，困上黨，上黨之民皆反為趙，天下不樂為秦民之日久矣。

translations.text: Qin once attacked Han, besieged Xingqiu, and trapped Shangdang. The Shangdang people all rebelled and went to Zhao. The world has long been unhappy being Qin's subjects.

sentences.zh: 今亡趙，北地入燕，東地入齊，南地入韓、魏，則君之所得民亡幾何人。

translations.text: Now if Zhao perishes, the northern lands will go to Yan, the eastern lands to Qi, the southern lands to Han and Wei—then how many subjects will you gain?

sentences.zh: 故不如因而割之，無以為武安君功也。」

translations.text: Therefore better to take advantage of this and divide territories without letting Lord Wu'an claim the merit.'

sentences.zh: 於是應侯言於秦王曰：「秦兵勞，請許韓、趙之割地以和，且休士卒。」

translations.text: Lord Ying then spoke to the King of Qin: 'Our troops are weary. Please allow us to accept Han and Zhao's territorial concessions for peace, and let our soldiers rest.'

sentences.zh: 王聽之，割韓垣雍、趙六城以和。

translations.text: The king listened and accepted Han's Huan Yong and six Zhao cities for peace.

sentences.zh: 正月，皆罷兵。

translations.text: In the first month, they all disbanded their armies.

sentences.zh: 武安君聞之，由是與應侯有隙。

translations.text: Lord Wu'an heard of this and from then on had enmity with Lord Ying.

In the tenth month of the forty-eighth year, Qin reestablished Shangdang Commandery. Qin divided their army into two: Wang He attacked Pi Lao and conquered it; Sima Geng pacified Taiyuan. Han and Zhao were afraid and sent Su Dai with rich bribes to persuade Qin's prime minister Lord Ying, saying: 'Has Lord Wu'an captured Ma Fuzi?' 'Yes.' 'Will he now besiege Handan?' 'Yes.' 'If Zhao perishes, the King of Qin will become hegemon. Lord Wu'an will become one of the Three Dukes. Lord Wu'an's victories for Qin—conquering over seventy cities, pacifying Yan and Ying in the south, taking Hanzhong, capturing Zhao Kuo's army in the north—even the achievements of Zhou Gong, Shao Gong, and Lu Wang would not surpass this. Now if Zhao perishes and the King of Qin becomes hegemon, Lord Wu'an will certainly become one of the Three Dukes. Can you serve beneath him? Even if you don't want to serve beneath him, you will have no choice.' Qin once attacked Han, besieged Xingqiu, and trapped Shangdang. The Shangdang people all rebelled and went to Zhao. The world has long been unhappy being Qin's subjects. Now if Zhao perishes, the northern lands will go to Yan, the eastern lands to Qi, the southern lands to Han and Wei—then how many subjects will you gain? Therefore better to take advantage of this and divide territories without letting Lord Wu'an claim the merit.' Lord Ying then spoke to the King of Qin: 'Our troops are weary. Please allow us to accept Han and Zhao's territorial concessions for peace, and let our soldiers rest.' The king listened and accepted Han's Huan Yong and six Zhao cities for peace. In the first month, they all disbanded their armies. Lord Wu'an heard of this and from then on had enmity with Lord Ying.

sentences.zh: 其九月，秦復發兵，使五大夫王陵攻趙邯鄲。

translations.text: In the ninth month, Qin sent troops again, dispatching grand master Wang Ling to attack Zhao's Handan.

sentences.zh: 是時武安君病，不任行。

translations.text: At this time Lord Wu'an was ill and could not go.

sentences.zh: 四十九年正月，陵攻邯鄲，少利，秦益發兵佐陵。

translations.text: In the first month of the forty-ninth year, Ling attacked Handan with little success. Qin sent more troops to assist Ling.

sentences.zh: 陵兵亡五校。

translations.text: Ling's troops lost five battalions.

sentences.zh: 武安君病愈，秦王欲使武安君代陵將。

translations.text: Lord Wu'an recovered from illness. The King of Qin wished to send Lord Wu'an to replace Ling as commander.

sentences.zh: 武安君言曰：「邯鄲實未易攻也。

translations.text: Lord Wu'an said: 'Handan is truly not easy to attack.

sentences.zh: 且諸侯救日至，彼諸侯怨秦之日久矣。

translations.text: Moreover, allied rescue forces arrive daily. Those allies have long resented Qin.

sentences.zh: 今秦雖破長平軍，而秦卒死者過半，國內空。

translations.text: Now although Qin broke the Changping army, over half our troops died, and the homeland is empty.

sentences.zh: 遠絕河山而爭人國都，趙應其內，諸侯攻其外，破秦軍必矣。

translations.text: To cross distant rivers and mountains to contest another's capital—Zhao responding from within, allies attacking from without—Qin army will certainly be broken.

sentences.zh: 不可。」

translations.text: It cannot be done.'

sentences.zh: 秦王自命，不行；

translations.text: The king personally commanded it, but he did not go.

sentences.zh: 乃使應侯請之，武安君終辭不肯行，遂稱病。

translations.text: He sent Lord Ying to request it. Lord Wu'an firmly refused and would not go, claiming illness.

In the ninth month, Qin sent troops again, dispatching grand master Wang Ling to attack Zhao's Handan. At this time Lord Wu'an was ill and could not go. In the first month of the forty-ninth year, Ling attacked Handan with little success. Qin sent more troops to assist Ling. Ling's troops lost five battalions. Lord Wu'an recovered from illness. The King of Qin wished to send Lord Wu'an to replace Ling as commander. Lord Wu'an said: 'Handan is truly not easy to attack. Moreover, allied rescue forces arrive daily. Those allies have long resented Qin. Now although Qin broke the Changping army, over half our troops died, and the homeland is empty. To cross distant rivers and mountains to contest another's capital—Zhao responding from within, allies attacking from without—Qin army will certainly be broken. It cannot be done.' The king personally commanded it, but he did not go. He sent Lord Ying to request it. Lord Wu'an firmly refused and would not go, claiming illness.

sentences.zh: 秦王使王龁代陵將，八九月圍邯鄲，不能拔。

translations.text: The king sent Wang He to replace Ling as commander. In the eighth and ninth months they besieged Handan but could not conquer it.

sentences.zh: 楚使春申君及魏公子將兵數十萬攻秦軍，秦軍多失亡。

translations.text: Chu sent Lord Chunshen and Wei sent its prince to lead tens of thousands of troops to attack Qin forces. Qin forces suffered many losses.

sentences.zh: 武安君言曰：「秦不聽臣計，今如何矣！」

translations.text: Lord Wu'an said: 'Qin did not listen to my plan. Now what can be done!'

sentences.zh: 秦王聞之，怒，彊起武安君，武安君遂稱病甐。

translations.text: The King of Qin heard this and grew angry. He forced Lord Wu'an to rise, but Lord Wu'an claimed illness and would not go.

sentences.zh: 應侯請之，不起。

translations.text: Lord Ying requested it, but he would not rise.

sentences.zh: 於是免武安君為士伍，遷之陰密。

translations.text: Thus they demoted Lord Wu'an to common soldier and exiled him to Yinmi.

sentences.zh: 武安君病，未能行。

translations.text: Lord Wu'an was ill and could not travel.

sentences.zh: 居三月，諸侯攻秦軍急，秦軍數卻，使者日至。

translations.text: After three months, the allied forces attacked Qin army urgently. Qin army retreated many times, with messengers arriving daily.

sentences.zh: 秦王乃使人遣白起，不得留咸陽中。

translations.text: The King of Qin sent men to expel Bai Qi, not allowing him to remain in Xianyang.

sentences.zh: 武安君既行，出咸陽西門十里，至杜郵。

translations.text: Lord Wu'an set out, leaving Xianyang's west gate for ten li, reaching Duyou.

sentences.zh: 秦昭王與應侯群臣議曰：「白起之遷，其意尚怏怏不服，有餘言。」

translations.text: King Zhao of Qin consulted with Lord Ying and his ministers: 'Bai Qi's exile—his heart is still resentful and unwilling, with many unspoken words.'

sentences.zh: 秦王乃使使者賜之劍，自裁。

translations.text: The king sent an envoy with a sword, commanding him to commit suicide.

sentences.zh: 武安君引劍將自剄，曰：「我何罪于天而至此哉？」

translations.text: Lord Wu'an drew his sword to cut his own throat, saying: 'What crime have I committed against Heaven to come to this?'

sentences.zh: 良久，曰：「我固當死。

translations.text: After a long time, he said: 'I certainly deserve to die.

sentences.zh: 長平之戰，趙卒降者數十萬人，我詐而盡阬之，是足以死。」

translations.text: At the battle of Changping, the Zhao troops who surrendered numbered several hundred thousand. I deceived them and buried them all alive. That is enough to deserve death.'

sentences.zh: 遂自殺。

translations.text: He then committed suicide.

sentences.zh: 武安君之死也，以秦昭王五十年十一月。

translations.text: Lord Wu'an died in the eleventh month of the fiftieth year of King Zhao of Qin.

sentences.zh: 死而非其罪，秦人憐之，鄉邑皆祭祀焉。

translations.text: He died though innocent of crime. The Qin people pitied him, and villages and townships all sacrificed to him.

The king sent Wang He to replace Ling as commander. In the eighth and ninth months they besieged Handan but could not conquer it. Chu sent Lord Chunshen and Wei sent its prince to lead tens of thousands of troops to attack Qin forces. Qin forces suffered many losses. Lord Wu'an said: 'Qin did not listen to my plan. Now what can be done!' The King of Qin heard this and grew angry. He forced Lord Wu'an to rise, but Lord Wu'an claimed illness and would not go. Lord Ying requested it, but he would not rise. Thus they demoted Lord Wu'an to common soldier and exiled him to Yinmi. Lord Wu'an was ill and could not travel. After three months, the allied forces attacked Qin army urgently. Qin army retreated many times, with messengers arriving daily. The King of Qin sent men to expel Bai Qi, not allowing him to remain in Xianyang. Lord Wu'an set out, leaving Xianyang's west gate for ten li, reaching Duyou. King Zhao of Qin consulted with Lord Ying and his ministers: 'Bai Qi's exile—his heart is still resentful and unwilling, with many unspoken words.' The king sent an envoy with a sword, commanding him to commit suicide. Lord Wu'an drew his sword to cut his own throat, saying: 'What crime have I committed against Heaven to come to this?' After a long time, he said: 'I certainly deserve to die. At the battle of Changping, the Zhao troops who surrendered numbered several hundred thousand. I deceived them and buried them all alive. That is enough to deserve death.' He then committed suicide. Lord Wu'an died in the eleventh month of the fiftieth year of King Zhao of Qin. He died though innocent of crime. The Qin people pitied him, and villages and townships all sacrificed to him.

sentences.zh: 王翦者，頻陽東鄉人也。

translations.text: Wang Jian was a man from the eastern village of Fenyin.

sentences.zh: 少而好兵，事秦始皇。

translations.text: As a youth he loved military affairs and served Qin Shihuang.

sentences.zh: 始皇十一年，翦將攻趙閼與，破之，拔九城，十八年，翦將攻趙。

translations.text: In the eleventh year of Shihuang, Jian commanded the attack on Zhao's Yan Yu and broke it, conquering nine cities. In the eighteenth year, Jian commanded the attack on Zhao.

sentences.zh: 歲餘，遂拔趙，趙王降，盡定趙地為郡。

translations.text: After more than a year, he conquered Zhao. The King of Zhao surrendered. They completely pacified Zhao territory as commanderies.

sentences.zh: 明年，燕使荊軻為賊於秦，秦王使王翦攻燕。

translations.text: The next year, Yan sent Jing Ke to assassinate Qin. The King of Qin sent Wang Jian to attack Yan.

sentences.zh: 燕王喜走遼東，翦遂定燕薊而還。

translations.text: King Xi of Yan fled to Liaodong. Jian then pacified Yan's Ji and returned.

sentences.zh: 秦使翦子王賁擊荊，荊兵敗。

translations.text: Qin sent Jian's son Wang Ben to attack Chu. Chu troops were defeated.

sentences.zh: 還擊魏，魏王降，遂定魏地。

translations.text: They returned to attack Wei. The King of Wei surrendered. They then pacified Wei territory.

Wang Jian was a man from the eastern village of Fenyin. As a youth he loved military affairs and served Qin Shihuang. In the eleventh year of Shihuang, Jian commanded the attack on Zhao's Yan Yu and broke it, conquering nine cities. In the eighteenth year, Jian commanded the attack on Zhao. After more than a year, he conquered Zhao. The King of Zhao surrendered. They completely pacified Zhao territory as commanderies. The next year, Yan sent Jing Ke to assassinate Qin. The King of Qin sent Wang Jian to attack Yan. King Xi of Yan fled to Liaodong. Jian then pacified Yan's Ji and returned. Qin sent Jian's son Wang Ben to attack Chu. Chu troops were defeated. They returned to attack Wei. The King of Wei surrendered. They then pacified Wei territory.

sentences.zh: 秦始皇既滅三晉，走燕王，而數破荊師。

translations.text: Qin Shihuang had already extinguished the Three Jin, driven away the King of Yan, and repeatedly broken Chu forces.

sentences.zh: 秦將李信者，年少壯勇，嘗以兵數千逐燕太子丹至於衍水中，卒破得丹，始皇以為賢勇。

translations.text: Among Qin's generals was Li Xin, young and vigorous. He once with several thousand troops pursued Yan's crown prince Dan to the middle of Yan River, finally breaking through and capturing Dan. Shihuang considered him worthy and brave.

sentences.zh: 於是始皇問李信：「吾欲攻取荊，於將軍度用幾何人而足？」

translations.text: Shihuang asked Li Xin: 'I wish to attack and conquer Chu. In your estimation, how many men will suffice?'

sentences.zh: 李信曰：「不過用二十萬人。」

translations.text: Li Xin said: 'No more than 200,000 men.'

sentences.zh: 始皇問王翦，王翦曰：「非六十萬人不可。」

translations.text: Shihuang asked Wang Jian. Wang Jian said: 'Without 600,000 men it cannot be done.'

sentences.zh: 始皇曰：「王將軍老矣，何怯也！

translations.text: Shihuang said: 'General Wang is old. Why so cowardly?

sentences.zh: 李將軍果勢壯勇，其言是也。」

translations.text: General Li is truly vigorous and brave. His words are correct.'

sentences.zh: 遂使李信及蒙恬將二十萬南伐荊。

translations.text: He sent Li Xin and Meng Tian to lead 200,000 men south to attack Chu.

sentences.zh: 王翦言不用，因謝病，歸老於頻陽。

translations.text: Wang Jian's advice was not used, so he claimed illness and returned to retire in Fenyin.

sentences.zh: 李信攻平與，蒙恬攻寢，大破荊軍。

translations.text: Li Xin attacked Ping Yu, Meng Tian attacked Qin. They greatly broke Chu forces.

sentences.zh: 信又攻鄢郢，破之，於是引兵而西，與蒙恬會城父。

translations.text: Xin attacked Yan Ying again and broke it. He then led troops west to meet Meng Tian at Chengfu.

sentences.zh: 荊人因隨之，三日三夜不頓舍，大破李信軍，入兩壁，殺七都尉，秦軍走。

translations.text: Chu people followed them, three days and nights without resting or camping, greatly broke Li Xin's army, entered two walls, killed seven commandants, and Qin army fled.

Qin Shihuang had already extinguished the Three Jin, driven away the King of Yan, and repeatedly broken Chu forces. Among Qin's generals was Li Xin, young and vigorous. He once with several thousand troops pursued Yan's crown prince Dan to the middle of Yan River, finally breaking through and capturing Dan. Shihuang considered him worthy and brave. Shihuang asked Li Xin: 'I wish to attack and conquer Chu. In your estimation, how many men will suffice?' Li Xin said: 'No more than 200,000 men.' Shihuang asked Wang Jian. Wang Jian said: 'Without 600,000 men it cannot be done.' Shihuang said: 'General Wang is old. Why so cowardly? General Li is truly vigorous and brave. His words are correct.' He sent Li Xin and Meng Tian to lead 200,000 men south to attack Chu. Wang Jian's advice was not used, so he claimed illness and returned to retire in Fenyin. Li Xin attacked Ping Yu, Meng Tian attacked Qin. They greatly broke Chu forces. Xin attacked Yan Ying again and broke it. He then led troops west to meet Meng Tian at Chengfu. Chu people followed them, three days and nights without resting or camping, greatly broke Li Xin's army, entered two walls, killed seven commandants, and Qin army fled.

sentences.zh: 始皇聞之，大怒，自馳如頻陽，見謝王翦曰：「寡人以不用將軍計，李信果辱秦軍。

translations.text: Shihuang heard of it and grew greatly angry. He raced personally to Fenyin and apologized to Wang Jian: 'I did not use your plan. Li Xin has indeed disgraced our Qin army.

sentences.zh: 今聞荊兵日進而西，將軍雖病，獨忍棄寡人乎！」

translations.text: Now I hear Chu troops advance daily westward. Though you are ill, can you bear to abandon me?'

sentences.zh: 王翦謝曰：「老臣罷病悖亂，唯大王更擇賢將。」

translations.text: Wang Jian apologized: 'Old minister is tired and ill, confused. I ask only that Your Majesty choose another worthy general.'

sentences.zh: 始皇謝曰：「已矣，將軍勿復言！」

translations.text: Shihuang apologized: 'Enough. General, speak no more!'

sentences.zh: 王翦曰：「大王必不得已用臣，非六十萬人不可。」

translations.text: Wang Jian said: 'If Your Majesty must use me, 600,000 men are indispensable.'

sentences.zh: 始皇曰：「為聽將軍計耳。」

translations.text: Shihuang said: 'I will follow your plan.'

sentences.zh: 於是王翦將兵六十萬人，始皇自送至灞上。

translations.text: Wang Jian led 600,000 troops. Shihuang personally saw him off to Bashang.

sentences.zh: 王翦行，請美田宅園池甚眾。

translations.text: As Wang Jian departed, he requested many fine fields, houses, and gardens.

sentences.zh: 始皇曰：「將軍行矣，何憂貧乎？」

translations.text: Shihuang said: 'General is departing. Why worry about poverty?'

sentences.zh: 王翦曰：「為大王將，有功終不得封侯，故及大王之向臣，臣亦及時以請園池為子孫業耳。」

translations.text: Wang Jian said: 'As Your Majesty's general, even with merit I will never be enfeoffed as marquess. So while Your Majesty favors me, I also take this opportunity to request gardens and pools as property for my descendants.'

sentences.zh: 始皇大笑。

translations.text: Shihuang laughed heartily.

sentences.zh: 王翦既至關，使使還請善田者五輩。

translations.text: Wang Jian reached the pass and sent messengers back five times requesting good fields.

sentences.zh: 或曰：「將軍之乞貸，亦已甚矣。」

translations.text: Some said: 'The general's begging is already excessive.'

sentences.zh: 王翦曰：「不然。

translations.text: Wang Jian said: 'Not so.

sentences.zh: 夫秦王怚而不信人。

translations.text: The King of Qin is suspicious and distrusts people.

sentences.zh: 今空秦國甲士而專委於我，我不多請田宅為子孫業以自堅，顧令秦王坐而疑我邪？」

translations.text: Now he empties Qin's armored soldiers and entrusts them all to me. If I don't request many fields and houses as property for my descendants to strengthen myself, won't the King of Qin sit and suspect me?'

Shihuang heard of it and grew greatly angry. He raced personally to Fenyin and apologized to Wang Jian: 'I did not use your plan. Li Xin has indeed disgraced our Qin army. Now I hear Chu troops advance daily westward. Though you are ill, can you bear to abandon me?' Wang Jian apologized: 'Old minister is tired and ill, confused. I ask only that Your Majesty choose another worthy general.' Shihuang apologized: 'Enough. General, speak no more!' Wang Jian said: 'If Your Majesty must use me, 600,000 men are indispensable.' Shihuang said: 'I will follow your plan.' Wang Jian led 600,000 troops. Shihuang personally saw him off to Bashang. As Wang Jian departed, he requested many fine fields, houses, and gardens. Shihuang said: 'General is departing. Why worry about poverty?' Wang Jian said: 'As Your Majesty's general, even with merit I will never be enfeoffed as marquess. So while Your Majesty favors me, I also take this opportunity to request gardens and pools as property for my descendants.' Shihuang laughed heartily. Wang Jian reached the pass and sent messengers back five times requesting good fields. Some said: 'The general's begging is already excessive.' Wang Jian said: 'Not so. The King of Qin is suspicious and distrusts people. Now he empties Qin's armored soldiers and entrusts them all to me. If I don't request many fields and houses as property for my descendants to strengthen myself, won't the King of Qin sit and suspect me?'

sentences.zh: 王翦果代李信擊荊。

translations.text: Wang Jian indeed replaced Li Xin to attack Chu.

sentences.zh: 荊聞王翦益軍而來，乃悉國中兵以拒秦。

translations.text: Chu heard Wang Jian was coming with increased forces and mobilized all their national troops to resist Qin.

sentences.zh: 王翦至，堅壁而守之，不肯戰。

translations.text: Wang Jian arrived and built firm fortifications to defend, refusing battle.

sentences.zh: 荊兵數出挑戰，終不出。

translations.text: Chu troops repeatedly came out to challenge, but he would not come out.

sentences.zh: 王翦日休士洗沐，而善飲食撫循之，親與士卒同食。

translations.text: Wang Jian daily let his soldiers rest and bathe, treating them well with food and care, personally eating the same as the soldiers.

sentences.zh: 久之，王翦使人問軍中戲乎？

translations.text: After a long time, Wang Jian sent someone to ask if the army was playing.

sentences.zh: 對曰：「方投石超距。」

translations.text: They replied: 'They are throwing stones and jumping.'

sentences.zh: 於是王翦曰：「士卒可用矣。」

translations.text: Wang Jian said: 'The soldiers can be used now.'

sentences.zh: 荊數挑戰而秦不出，乃引而東。

translations.text: Chu repeatedly challenged but Qin would not come out. Chu then withdrew eastward.

sentences.zh: 翦因舉兵追之，令壯士擊，大破荊軍。

translations.text: Jian raised his troops to pursue them, commanding brave warriors to strike. He greatly broke Chu army.

sentences.zh: 至蘄南，殺其將軍項燕，荊兵遂敗走。

translations.text: Reaching south of Qi, he killed their general Xiang Yan. Chu troops fled in defeat.

sentences.zh: 秦因乘勝略定荊地城邑。

translations.text: Qin took advantage of victory to sweep and pacify Chu cities and towns.

sentences.zh: 歲餘，虜荊王負芻，竟平荊地為郡縣。

translations.text: After more than a year, they captured Chu King Fu Chou and finally pacified Chu territory as commanderies and counties.

sentences.zh: 因南征百越之君。

translations.text: They then campaigned south against the lords of Baiyue.

sentences.zh: 而王翦子王賁，與李信破定燕、齊地。

translations.text: Wang Jian's son Wang Ben, together with Li Xin, conquered and pacified Yan and Qi territories.

Wang Jian indeed replaced Li Xin to attack Chu. Chu heard Wang Jian was coming with increased forces and mobilized all their national troops to resist Qin. Wang Jian arrived and built firm fortifications to defend, refusing battle. Chu troops repeatedly came out to challenge, but he would not come out. Wang Jian daily let his soldiers rest and bathe, treating them well with food and care, personally eating the same as the soldiers. After a long time, Wang Jian sent someone to ask if the army was playing. They replied: 'They are throwing stones and jumping.' Wang Jian said: 'The soldiers can be used now.' Chu repeatedly challenged but Qin would not come out. Chu then withdrew eastward. Jian raised his troops to pursue them, commanding brave warriors to strike. He greatly broke Chu army. Reaching south of Qi, he killed their general Xiang Yan. Chu troops fled in defeat. Qin took advantage of victory to sweep and pacify Chu cities and towns. After more than a year, they captured Chu King Fu Chou and finally pacified Chu territory as commanderies and counties. They then campaigned south against the lords of Baiyue. Wang Jian's son Wang Ben, together with Li Xin, conquered and pacified Yan and Qi territories.

sentences.zh: 秦始皇二十六年，盡并天下，王氏、蒙氏功為多，名施於後世。

translations.text: In the twenty-sixth year of Qin Shihuang, they completely unified the world. The Wang and Meng clans had the greatest merit, their fame extending to later generations.
In the twenty-sixth year of Qin Shihuang, they completely unified the world. The Wang and Meng clans had the greatest merit, their fame extending to later generations.

sentences.zh: 秦二世之時，王翦及其子賁皆已死，而又滅蒙氏。

translations.text: In the time of Qin Ershi, Wang Jian and his son Ben had both already died, and they also extinguished the Meng clan.

sentences.zh: 陳勝之反秦，秦使王翦之孫王離擊趙，圍趙王及張耳鉅鹿城。

translations.text: When Chen Sheng rebelled against Qin, Qin sent Wang Jian's grandson Wang Li to attack Zhao, besieging King Zhao and Zhang Er at Julu City.

sentences.zh: 或曰：「王離，秦之名將也。

translations.text: Some said: 'Wang Li is Qin's famous general.

sentences.zh: 今將彊秦之兵，攻新造之趙，舉之必矣。」

translations.text: Now commanding strong Qin's troops to attack newly founded Zhao—it will certainly succeed.'

sentences.zh: 客曰：「不然。

translations.text: A guest said: 'Not so.

sentences.zh: 夫為將三世者必敗。

translations.text: Generals of the third generation will certainly fail.

sentences.zh: 必敗者何也？

translations.text: Why will they certainly fail?

sentences.zh: 必其所殺伐多矣，其後受其不祥。

translations.text: They must have killed and conquered much. Afterward they receive their misfortune.

sentences.zh: 今王離已三世將矣。」

translations.text: Now Wang Li is already a third-generation general.'

sentences.zh: 居無何，項羽救趙，擊秦軍，果虜王離，王離軍遂降諸侯。

translations.text: Before long, Xiang Yu rescued Zhao, attacked Qin army, and indeed captured Wang Li. Wang Li's army surrendered to the feudal lords.

In the time of Qin Ershi, Wang Jian and his son Ben had both already died, and they also extinguished the Meng clan. When Chen Sheng rebelled against Qin, Qin sent Wang Jian's grandson Wang Li to attack Zhao, besieging King Zhao and Zhang Er at Julu City. Some said: 'Wang Li is Qin's famous general. Now commanding strong Qin's troops to attack newly founded Zhao—it will certainly succeed.' A guest said: 'Not so. Generals of the third generation will certainly fail. Why will they certainly fail? They must have killed and conquered much. Afterward they receive their misfortune. Now Wang Li is already a third-generation general.' Before long, Xiang Yu rescued Zhao, attacked Qin army, and indeed captured Wang Li. Wang Li's army surrendered to the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 太史公曰：鄙語云「尺有所短，寸有所長」。

translations.text: The Grand Historian says: The common saying goes 'A foot has its shortcomings, an inch has its strengths.'

sentences.zh: 白起料敵合變，出奇無窮，聲震天下，然不能救患於應侯。

translations.text: Bai Qi assessed enemies and adapted to changes, deploying surprises without limit, his fame shook the world, yet he could not save himself from Lord Ying's schemes.

sentences.zh: 王翦為秦將，夷六國，當是時，翦為宿將，始皇師之，然不能輔秦建德，固其根本，偷合取容，以至圽身。

translations.text: Wang Jian as Qin's general extinguished the six states. At that time, Jian was an old general whom Shihuang relied on, yet he could not assist Qin in establishing virtue and strengthening its foundations, but instead curried favor and accommodated himself, leading to his downfall.

sentences.zh: 及孫王離為項羽所虜，不亦宜乎！

translations.text: When his grandson Wang Li was captured by Xiang Yu, was it not fitting?

sentences.zh: 彼各有所短也。

translations.text: They each have their shortcomings.

The Grand Historian says: The common saying goes 'A foot has its shortcomings, an inch has its strengths.' Bai Qi assessed enemies and adapted to changes, deploying surprises without limit, his fame shook the world, yet he could not save himself from Lord Ying's schemes. Wang Jian as Qin's general extinguished the six states. At that time, Jian was an old general whom Shihuang relied on, yet he could not assist Qin in establishing virtue and strengthening its foundations, but instead curried favor and accommodated himself, leading to his downfall. When his grandson Wang Li was captured by Xiang Yu, was it not fitting? They each have their shortcomings.
